facts.text: Appellant was sitting in a third class compartment of the Amritsar Kalka train standing on Platform No. 5 of the Amritsar Railway Station on February 11, 1958.
Appellant was searched by a Customs Official and some bars of gold were found tied round his waist.
Gold bars seized: four of base metal, rest pure gold; some bearing stamp of Johnson Matthey Co. Ltd., 999-10 tolas; 2-1/4 bars bore marks of N.M. Rothschild Sons 10 tolas 990-0.
No permit from the Reserve Bank to import this gold was produced by the appellant.
Under the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, importation of gold without permit prohibited and contravention punishable under s.23-A read with s.167(81) of Sea Customs Act.
Appellant prosecuted under s.23A of Foreign Exchange Regulation Act and s.167(81) of Sea Customs Act.
Appellant's defence: not in possession of gold bars; taken from attache case left by a stranger under the seat.
Additional District Magistrate held offence proved, convicted appellant, sentenced to one year rigorous imprisonment.
Appeal to Sessions Judge: sentence reduced to 8 months rigorous imprisonment; accepted prosecution testimony, rejected defence.
Revision to Punjab High Court: sentence reduced to six months rigorous imprisonment; rejected appellant's plea.
Trial court accepted testimony of Customs Officials; held defence false; gold worth Rs. 14,000/- found in possession.
Sessions Judge accepted Customs Officials' testimony, held defence false, gold in possession of appellant.
Two Customs officers testified: Inspector Satnam Singh (Land Customs) and Deputy Superintendent A.N. Kapur.
Nothing in cross-examination indicated officers lacked reasonable belief that goods were smuggled.

legal_issues.text: Constitutionality of s.178A of the Sea Customs Act, 1878.
Whether prosecution must prove goods were of foreign origin and reasonableness of Customs Officer's belief for s.178A to apply.

petitioner_arguments.text: Gold bars taken from attache case left by stranger under seat; not in possession.
Before presumption under s.178A applicable, prosecution must prove goods of foreign origin (imported from abroad) and reasonableness of belief they were smuggled; s.178A relates only to customs duty.
Mere foreign stamps do not prove foreign origin; could be on spurious Indian gold.

respondent_arguments.text: Testimony of Customs Officials reliable; gold found tied round appellant's waist.

court_reasoning.text: s.178A held constitutional in Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty.
New point on foreign origin and reasonable belief not agitated in courts below.
s.178A: Where goods seized under Act in reasonable belief they are smuggled goods, burden on person from whose possession seized to prove they are not smuggled.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies to gold; burden shifts once seized on reasonable belief.

court_reasoning.text: No indication officers lacked reasonable belief; not suggested in cross-exam or lower court findings.
Onus on accused to show goods not smuggled (not foreign origin without duty paid); not on prosecution to prove Indian origin.

holdings.text: No requirement for prosecution to prove foreign origin or reasonableness of belief beyond seizure under the section; burden on possessor.

precedents_cited.case_name: Collector of Customs, Madras v. Nathella Sampathu Chetty

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Presumption on smuggled goods; offence for contravention

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits gold import without permit; punishable with Sea Customs provisions

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; upheld conviction and sentence reduction by High Court; rejected new contention on s.178A applicability.

key_quotes.text: Where any goods to which this section applies are seized under this Act in the reasonable belief that they are smuggled goods, the burden of proving that they are not smuggled goods shall be on the person from whose possession the goods were seized.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Verbatim text of s.178A explaining presumption and burden

key_quotes.text: The onus is on him to show that the goods are not smuggled, that is, not of foreign origin on which duty is not paid. The onus is not on the prosecution to show that the goods are not of Indian origin.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on burden of proof under s.178A
